metadata.titleEn: A global dataset on future surface climate from the Community Earth System Model 2.0 from 2015 to 2070 or 2100
metadata.description: This dataset is generated by the Community Earth System Model version 2.0 (CESM2.0) under the Representative Concentration Pathway 8.5 (RCP8.5) scenario, representing a global land surface climate dataset. To quantify the impact of future urbanization on global climate change, the dataset utilizes future scenario surface data with three different levels of urbanization development, resulting in three sub-datasets: (1) SSP585_UC_BNU, (2) SSP585_DU_BNU, and (3) SSP585_DU_GAO. In SSP585_UC_BNU, urbanization levels remain at the current level, using the 2020 global urbanization products simulated by He et al. (2021) under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5 (SSP5) scenario. In SSP585_DU_BNU, urbanization levels dynamically develop, utilizing the dynamic global urbanization products simulated by He et al. (2021) under the SSP5 scenario for the years 2020 to 2070. SSP585_DU_GAO adopts a faster urbanization rate, using the dynamic global urbanization products simulated by Gao & O'Neill (2020) under the SSP5 scenario for the years 2020 to 2070. The time cover for the SSP585_UC_BNU dataset is from 2015 to 2100, with monthly, daily, and hourly temporal resolutions. The hourly-scale data covers the years 2019 to 2023 and 2096 to 2100. The time cover for the SSP585_DU_BNU dataset is from 2015 to 2070, with a monthly temporal resolution. The time cover for the SSP585_DU_GAO dataset is from 2015 to 2100, with a monthly temporal resolution. The spatial resolution for all three sub-datasets is 0.9°×1.25°. The dataset includes variables at both grid and sub-grid scales, encompassing basic meteorological elements, surface energy fluxes, runoff, and more. Specific information about the simulated data can be found in the paper Zhang, K., Lee, X., Schultz, N. M., Zhao, L., He, C., Huang, Q., .Liu, Z., Chu, H & Zhao, J. (2023). A global dataset on subgrid land surface climate (2015–2100) from the Community Earth System Model. Geoscience Data Journal, 10(2), 208-219. DOI: 10.1002/gdj3.153. The dataset can be used for the research on the climate effect of urbanization, deforestation, lake expansion / shrinking.
metadata.instructions: File Naming: Saved in NetCDF-4 format. For SSP585_UC_BNU, the file name is "b.e21.SSP585UC_IndividualSoil_XX_SUB_SSS_TTT". Here, "XX" represents the variable name, "SUB" represents the sub-grid type, "SSS" represents the temporal resolution, and "TTT" represents the data's time span. For example, "b.e21.SSP585UC_IndividualSoil_tasu_Urban_Monthly_201501-210012.nc" denotes simulated monthly temperature data for urban sub-grids from January 2015 to December 2100. For SSP585_DU_BNU, the file name is "b.e213.BSSP585.SSP5_DU.clm2.h0.XXXX-MM". Here, "XXXX" represents the year, and "MM" represents the month. For instance, "b.e213.BSSP585.SSP5_DU.clm2.h0.2015-01" indicates simulated data for January 2015. For SSP585_DU_GAO, the file name is "b.e213.BSSP585.SSP5_DU_Gao.clm2.h0.XXXX-MM". Similarly, "XXXX" represents the year, and "MM" represents the month. For example, "b.e213.BSSP585.SSP5_DU_Gao.clm2.h0.2015-01" signifies simulated data for January 2015. Data Retrieval Method: Users can use Python, MATLAB, and other relevant software to access the data.

background: The urban heat island (UHI) refers to the phenomenon of higher temperature in a city than in its adjacent rural land. The UHI intensity can be quantified as the urban–rural contrast in surface temperature (SUHI) and in near-surface air temperature (AUHI). Generally, the SUHI intensity is computed from the city-wide mean surface temperature and the mean surface temperature of rural pixels in a buffer zone outside the city. Controls of spatial and temporal patterns in the SUHI are well understood. In comparison, our understanding of the AUHI patterns and their controlling factors is still primitive. Over the diurnal cycle, the SUHI peaks during the daytime, but the AUHI is usually greater at night. Studies that compare the SUHI and the AUHI across climate zones show that the SUHI is stronger than the AUHI by an average of 1.1 ± 1.1 K during the daytime and 0.3 ± 1.5 K during the nighttime. In comparison with the SUHI, the spatial variations in the AUHI and the associated biophysical controls are less understood. The SUHI is generally stronger in wetter climates. With regard to the spatial gradient in the AUHI, one study showed that the AUHI is negatively correlated with climate wetness, but another revealed that the AUHI is uncorrelated with precipitation.
research objective: In this study, we used the data generated by an urban climate model to investigate spatial variations in the AUHI and the underlying climate and ecological drivers. Our first objective is to investigate whether the spatial variations in the AUHI are primarily controlled by the background climate (temperature and precipitation) or by background ecological attributes, such as leaf area index (LAI). Our second objective is to perform attribution analysis of the AUHI intensity.
challenges: One limitation of the present modeling framework is its simplistic representation of the urban landscape. Furthermore, the current version of CLM does not have the capacity to handle urban vegetation. The computational cost would be prohibitive to run such a model over 5 years and for more than 300 cities, as was done in the present study. The blending height assumption also deserves attention.
methods: In this study, the data generated by an urban climate model were used to investigate the spatial variations of the AUHI across China and the underlying climate and ecological drivers. A total of 355 urban clusters were used. We performed an attribution analysis of the AUHI to elucidate the mechanisms underlying its formation. In our study, the AUHI intensity is quantified as the 2-m air temperature difference between the urban and rural tiles (∆T2) in the same model grid cell.
dataset: The simulation was conducted at a 0.9°×1.25° resolution under the Representative Concentration Pathway 8.5 (RCP8.5) scenario from 2015 to 2100. There are 355 grid cells containing both urban and rural tiles across China. They fall into three climate zones: humid (201 grids), semi-humid (118 grids), and semi-arid (36 grids) according to the Köppen–Geiger climate classification. We only used the variables of urban and rural subgrid tiles at hourly intervals from 2019 to 2023.
findings: The results show that the midday AUHI is negatively correlated with climate wetness (humid: 0.34 K; semi-humid: 0.50 K; semi-arid: 0.73 K). The annual mean midnight AUHI does not show discernible spatial patterns, but is generally stronger than the midday AUHI. The urban–rural difference in convection efficiency is the largest contributor to the midday AUHI in the humid (0.32 ± 0.09 K) and the semi-arid (0.36 ± 0.11 K) climate zones. The release of anthropogenic heat from urban land is the dominant contributor to the midnight AUHI in all three climate zones. The rural vegetation density is the most important driver of the daytime and nighttime AUHI spatial variations. A spatial covariance analysis revealed that this vegetation influence is manifested mainly through its regulation of heat storage in rural land.

Disjunctive.Question: Is the simulation data under the RCP8.5 scenario more useful for studying urban climate effects or rural climate effects?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection method is used to quantify the urban heat island (UHI) intensity?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to quantify the urban heat island (UHI) effect in different climate zones?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involves using an urban climate model to analyze spatial variations in the near-surface air temperature difference between urban and rural areas. This method was applied to 355 urban clusters across China, utilizing hourly data from 2019 to 2023 under the RCP8.5 scenario.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when modeling urban landscapes for climate studies?
Example.Answer: One challenge is the simplistic representation of urban landscapes in current models, which may not adequately account for urban vegetation. This limitation can hinder the accurate simulation of urban climate dynamics and increase computational costs.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes both urban and rural climate variables for studying the urban heat island effect?
Example.Answer: A dataset includes grid cells containing urban and rural subgrid tiles at a resolution of 0.9°×1.25°, covering 355 grid cells across humid, semi-humid, and semi-arid climate zones in China. It provides hourly data from 2019 to 2023 under the RCP8.5 scenario, enabling the study of urban and rural climate contrasts.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of future climate datasets generated using the CESM2.0 model under different urbanization scenarios?
Feature Specification.Answer: global land surface climate data, spatial resolution of 0.9°×1.25°, different urbanization levels, spans various time periods and resolutions, monthly data, daily data, hourly data, variables at grid and subgrid scales, basic meteorological elements, surface energy fluxes

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential attributes of subgrid land surface climate data used for climate effect research?
Feature Specification.Answer: basic meteorological elements, land surface energy fluxes, runoff, different temporal resolutions, various subgrid types (urban, suburban, rural)

Definition.Question: What does 'subgrid land surface climate data' mean in the context of climate modeling?
Definition.Answer: Subgrid land surface climate data refers to the inclusion of finer-scale variables within a larger grid cell in climate models, capturing different land surface types such as urban areas, rural lands, forests, and lakes, to better represent the diversity and complexity of land surface conditions and their interactions with the atmosphere.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'representative concentration pathway' in climate simulation scenarios?
Definition.Answer: A representative concentration pathway (RCP) is a greenhouse gas concentration trajectory adopted in climate modeling to project different future climate scenarios based on varying levels of anthropogenic emissions. In this context, RCP8.5 represents a high-emission scenario used to simulate future climate conditions.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection resolution of a global climate dataset under the RCP8.5 scenario compare to that used for urban heat island studies across different climate zones?
Comparison.Answer: The global climate dataset under the RCP8.5 scenario uses a spatial resolution of 0.9°×1.25° and includes both monthly and hourly data, whereas the urban heat island studies use a similar resolution for 355 grid cells but focus on hourly intervals from 2019 to 2023, specifically for urban and rural tiles in China across three climate zones.

Interpretation.Question: How can the differences in urban and rural subgrid tiles' data at a 0.9°×1.25° resolution from 2015 to 2100 help infer the impact of urbanization on climate patterns?
Interpretation.Answer: The differences in urban and rural subgrid tiles' data can help infer the impact of urbanization on climate patterns by quantifying the urban heat island intensity as the air temperature difference between urban and rural areas. This can reveal how urbanization affects surface temperature and ecological drivers, contributing to a better understanding of climate change impacts.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when using urban climate models to simulate spatial variations in the AUHI across different climate zones, and how could these influence the interpretation of the results?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in using urban climate models include simplistic representation of urban landscapes and limitations in handling urban vegetation. These challenges can influence the interpretation of results by potentially underestimating the complexity of urban environments, impacting the accuracy of attributing variations in AUHI to specific climate and ecological drivers.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying factors contribute to the challenges in accurately modeling urban heat island effects using climate models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in modeling urban heat island effects arise from a simplistic representation of urban landscapes and the lack of capability in current models to handle urban vegetation. Additionally, high computational costs associated with running models over extensive time periods and for numerous cities, as well as assumptions like blending height, contribute to these challenges.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do spatial variations in the atmospheric urban heat island (AUHI) show different patterns compared to surface urban heat island (SUHI) across various climate zones?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Spatial variations in AUHI differ from SUHI due to less understood biophysical controls and their association with spatial gradients. While SUHI is generally stronger in wetter climates, AUHI's relationship with climate wetness and precipitation is less clear, with some studies showing a negative correlation and others showing no correlation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What reasons lead to the selection of Köppen–Geiger climate classification for categorizing climate zones in urban heat island studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Köppen–Geiger climate classification is used to categorize climate zones in urban heat island studies because it provides a broad delineation of climate types, allowing for an understanding of how urban and rural tiles are distributed across humid, semi-humid, and semi-arid zones. This classification helps in analyzing the contributions and variations of AUHI patterns across diverse environmental conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of subgrid scale variables in climate models affect the prediction of climate change impacts on urban and rural areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of subgrid scale variables in climate models allows for a more detailed representation of different land cover types such as urban, rural, and vegetation elements. This enhanced granularity can improve the understanding and prediction of climate change impacts, including the urban heat island intensity and the spatial variations in temperature between urban and rural areas, thereby providing a more nuanced insight into local climate effects.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the implications of using different time resolutions in climate models for understanding the diurnal cycle of urban heat islands?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using different time resolutions in climate models can significantly affect the understanding of the diurnal cycle of urban heat islands. High temporal resolution data, such as hourly intervals, provide detailed insights into the variations of urban heat island intensity throughout the day and night, allowing researchers to capture peak effects and subtle temporal patterns that are crucial for understanding the dynamics of urban climate phenomena.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of creating a dataset using the CESM2.0 model under the RCP8.5 scenario with varying urbanization levels?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to quantify the impact of future urbanization on global climate change and to provide data that can be used to study climate effects caused by changes in land surfaces such as urbanization, deforestation, and lake variations under different future scenarios.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to investigate spatial variations in the AUHI using data from an urban climate model across China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to understand the spatial variations in the AUHI because it helps identify the underlying climate and ecological drivers that control these variations, which can inform urban planning and climate mitigation strategies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in using an urban climate model to investigate the spatial variations of anthropogenic heat island effects across different climate zones?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involve using data generated by an urban climate model to analyze spatial variations of the anthropogenic urban heat island (AUHI) across China. This includes selecting 355 urban clusters, performing attribution analysis of AUHI, and quantifying AUHI intensity as the 2-m air temperature difference between urban and rural tiles in the same model grid cell.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the temporal resolution of climate data managed in scenarios ranging from 2015 to 2100 for modeling urbanization impacts on global climate?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Temporal resolution is managed by using monthly data for scenarios from 2015 to 2070/2100, with hourly data available for specific periods such as 2019-2023 and 2096-2100 in the SSP585_UC_BNU subset. This comprehensive temporal framework supports the analysis of urbanization impacts on climate.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the simulation of future urbanization impacts on global climate using climate models?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies involve using the Community Earth System Model version 2.0 (CESM2.0) under the Representative Concentration Pathway 8.5 (RCP8.5) scenario. This includes simulating different urbanization levels and analyzing subgrid land surface climate data to understand the impact of urbanization on global climate change.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset focusing on the urban heat island effect not capture variations in the near-surface air temperature (AUHI) as effectively as surface temperature variations (SUHI)?
Expectation.Answer: A dataset might not capture variations in AUHI as effectively as SUHI because our understanding of AUHI patterns and their controlling factors is still primitive compared to SUHI. Additionally, the simplistic representation of urban landscapes in current models and the lack of capacity to handle urban vegetation can limit the accuracy of AUHI data.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using urban climate models to simulate future climate scenarios under different urbanization levels?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of using urban climate models can be evaluated based on how well they capture the spatial variations in urban heat islands and the influence of different urbanization levels on climate variables such as air temperature and precipitation. The models' ability to incorporate different scenarios, such as those under the Representative Concentration Pathway 8.5, provides a comprehensive framework to simulate potential future conditions. However, limitations such as simplistic urban landscape representation and the lack of urban vegetation handling suggest areas for model improvement to enhance the accuracy and reliability of the simulations.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in collecting and utilizing high-resolution data for urban climate studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges in collecting and utilizing high-resolution data for urban climate studies include the computational cost of managing large datasets, particularly when simulating over extended periods and numerous urban clusters. The blending height assumption and the simplistic representation of urban landscapes in current models may limit the accuracy of the data collected. Additionally, the integration of subgrid-scale variables and the need for detailed ecological and climate data can complicate data collection efforts, requiring advanced modeling techniques and substantial computational resources.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the prospects for developing more sophisticated datasets that account for urban vegetation and its impact on urban climate models?
Judgmental.Answer: The prospects for developing more sophisticated datasets that account for urban vegetation in urban climate models are promising but require advancements in data collection techniques and model capabilities. Incorporating urban vegetation could improve the representation of biophysical processes and their influence on urban heat islands. This development could enhance the attribution analysis of urban heat intensity by considering factors such as leaf area index and rural vegetation density. However, achieving this sophistication would necessitate overcoming current limitations in model frameworks and increasing computational efficiency to handle the additional complexity.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how urbanization levels are quantified in climate models for future scenarios.
Assertion.Answer: The datasets use different urbanization scenarios based on current urbanization levels and dynamic models. For example, SSP585_UC_BNU maintains current urbanization levels using 2020 data, while SSP585_DU_BNU and SSP585_DU_GAO use dynamic urbanization products for 2020~2070, with varying rates of development.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how the spatial resolution of climate datasets affects the understanding of urban-rural contrasts.
Assertion.Answer: The datasets have a spatial resolution of 0.9°×1.25°, which includes subgrid variables for urban and rural areas. This resolution allows for the analysis of urban-rural contrasts, such as the urban heat island effect, by comparing differences in variables like air temperature across grid cells containing both urban and rural tiles.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how anthropogenic heat release is factored into climate models for urban areas.
Assertion.Answer: Anthropogenic heat release is considered a dominant contributor to the urban heat island effect, particularly during the night. In the dataset, this factor is examined as a major influence on the urban-rural temperature difference, affecting the spatial variations in climate zones categorized as humid, semi-humid, and semi-arid.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential challenges in collecting data for urban heat island effects over diverse climate zones using a global climate model.
Request/Directive.Answer: One limitation of the present modeling framework is its simplistic representation of the urban landscape. Furthermore, the current version of the Community Land Model (CLM) does not have the capacity to handle urban vegetation. The computational cost would be prohibitive to run such a model over 5 years and for more than 300 cities, which presents a significant challenge in data collection for urban heat island effects across diverse climate zones.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methods used to quantify urban heat island intensity in climate modeling, particularly focusing on spatial and temporal variations.
Request/Directive.Answer: In this study, the data generated by an urban climate model were used to investigate the spatial variations of the AUHI across China and the underlying climate and ecological drivers. The AUHI intensity is quantified as the 2-m air temperature difference between the urban and rural tiles (∆T2) in the same model grid cell. This approach allows for an exploration of spatial and temporal variations in urban heat island intensity.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore methods for incorporating urban and rural subgrid tiles data at various temporal resolutions into climate models.
Request/Directive.Answer: The simulation was conducted at a 0.9°×1.25° resolution under the Representative Concentration Pathway 8.5 (RCP8.5) scenario from 2015 to 2100. There are 355 grid cells containing both urban and rural tiles across China. Variables of urban and rural subgrid tiles were used at hourly intervals from 2019 to 2023, demonstrating a method for incorporating data at various temporal resolutions into climate models.
